Ok, I know why. I had to derive a whole theorem for it tho (on my own, hehe)  What the result says is that, if r=f(theta) and theta goes from theta 1 to theta 2,  r=-f(theta - (2n+1)pi), where theta goes from (theta 1 + (2n+1)pi) to (theta 2 + (2n+1)pi), IS THE SAME CURVE. How kawaii is that!!  The extraneous solution I got above fits this theory, so we can say it's the same curve. You could say the range changes, because my theorem says so, but since both solutions are periodic in 2pi, any range of span 2pi should give you all values, but the path you take will vary ig, but you don't need to worry about range in this particular problem.  It's not a trivial detail though, maybe that's why professor didn't mention it.  If there's actually an easier way to see this without deriving a whole new result please let me know...

Btw I did test my theory on desmos by putting in the predicted constraints & typing in as many f(theta)s I could think of, some ugly ones too, it holds! Let me know if anyone reading this finds a function that doesn't satisfy the theorem (test in desmos before telling me though, obviously)

Here's the reason you might be looking for.  The way we define polar coordinates is that we can use a negative value for r or positive value for r to depict the same coordinate given that we shift cos and sine by pi (i.e., cos(x + pi) = - cos(x) and same for pi). But the thing is, we can pick any angle we want for our polar equations and eventually we'll get a repeating loop because the cosines and sines are periodic with the same period. So any coordinate corresponding to some negative r for some angle cosine will also be hit again when r is positive and pi is added to that angle (just pi in this case since we haven't done any scale changes). Generalize this for all the valid combinations of r and theta, and we end up retracing the same curve, so the -r case is not important.  The professor hints at this in the last lecture when he introduces polar coordinates and says that r = " + OR - " sqrt(x^2 + y^2), meaning r is the union of both since we can really always pick either one. Of course r^2 = x^2 + y^2 doesn't have the uncertainty of which one we have to pick.

I know that kepler's law uses circular orbits as a basic assumptions, but there is a more complicated version of kepler's third law with correction of the radius to model an elliptical path.

Where did he say the radius is constant?  He said the angular momentum is constant, which is true since the net external torque is zero.  His expression for angular momentum is correct assuming up to a constant factor (the mass).

read dA =r^2 / 2 dθ as   ΔA ≈ r^2 / 2 Δθ (equations with differentials, ie, equations with dx, dy just independently floating around,  are shorthands for exactly this, according to my understanding)  The fact that this works for small angles should be convincing, because the radius roughly remains the same, so theres going to be a small error that gets smaller ans smaller as Δθ gets smaller.  Now, divide the equation by Δt, the small change in time corresponding to the change Δθ.  ΔA/Δt ≈ r^2 / 2 (Δθ/Δt)  Sub for this fact: Δθ = θ(t+Δt) - θ(t)  ΔA/Δt ≈ r^2 / 2 ( (θ(t+Δt) - θ(t) ) /Δt)  Take the limit for Δt->0  lim Δt->0 ΔA/Δt = lim Δt->0  r^2 / 2 ( (θ(t+Δt) - θ(t) ) /Δt)       -->>>> (notice that ≈ is switched out for =, which should make sense)  Something here looks exactly like the definition of differenciation!  That turns to,  dA/dt = r^2/2 dθ/dt  Notice how taking Δt->0 has no effect on r whatsoever. That should answer your question.  Anyways, note that you dont have to think of dA/dt as the differenciation of a function, you could think of it as tiny area sweeped in a small time, but formally, it is the differenciation of a function A(t), that accumulates area sweeped starting at some reference time (could be literally any point in time, you choose).

I think you are right. I think the formula professor gives is not wrong, since it perfectly fits the following verification of the area of circle. But i think he made a mistake in the formula. In the formula, θ actually means the angle rather than the arc length. And if you refer to the following example he gives, r=2*a*cosθ shows the relationship between the angle and the distance. That is why it can verify the area of a circle perfectly.

In order to find the area of the sector of the circle, which is not more than a fraction of the total whole, you multiply this fraction by the total area to get the area of the sector. He has used radians instead of number of degrees since the formula of the circle contains pi which as you know is a number in radians not degrees (180)
The area of sector is (theta/360)*pi*radius ².

Thank you for this discussion. I was confused about this for a good 30 minutes. Just decided to look at the comments haha.  Yes the delta(θ) refers to the angle of arc, not the arc length. It would be unwise here to include a new variable to describe the arc length, since it can be derived from the radius and angle.
